questions.text: Torsades de pointes (French for “twisting of the points”) is one of several types of life-threatening heart rhythm disturbances. In the case of torsades de pointes (TdP), the heart's two lower chambers, called the ventricles, beat faster than and out of sync with the upper chambers, called the atria. The most important feature of Torsades de Pointes is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Prolonged QTc interval Torsades De Pointes Options A, B, and D are not the most important feature in torsade de pointes.

questions.text: Congenital long QT syndrome (LQTS) is a hereditary cardiac disease characterized by a prolongation of the QT interval at basal ECG and by a high risk of life-threatening arrhythmias. Congenital long QT syndrome causes death due to?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia All forms of the long QT syndrome involve an abnormal repolarization of the heart. The abnormal repolarization causes differences in the refractory period of the heart muscle cells. After depolarizations can be propagated to neighboring cells due to the differences in the refractory periods, leading to re-entrant ventricular arrhythmias like torsades de pointes/ polymorphic VT. Early After-Depolarizations (EADs) that are seen in LQTS are due to the re-opening of L- type calcium channels during the plateau phase of the cardiac action potential. Since adrenergic stimulation can increase the activity of these channels this is an explanation for why the risk of sudden death in individuals with LQTS is increased during increased adrenergic states (i.e., exercise, excitement) especially since repolarization is impaired. Normally during adrenergic states, repolarizing currents will also be enhanced to shorten the action potential. In the absence of the shortening and the presence of increased L-type calcium current, EADs may arise. The Jervell and Lange- Nielsen syndrome (JLNS) is an autosomal recessive form of LQTS with associated congenital deafness. It is caused specifically by mutation of the KCNE1 and KCNQ1 genes In untreated individuals with JLNS, about 50 percent die by the age of 15 years due to ventricular arrhythmias Romano-Ward syndrome is an autosomal dominant form of LQTS that is not associated with deafness. Options A, C, and D are not the correct choices.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female was admitted to the hospital with C/o breathlessness. Her ECG shows a QRS amplitude of < 10mm in the chest leads. Factors responsible for such an ECG change include all of the following except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left Ventricular hypertrophy The above ECG showed a QRS amplitude of < 10mm in the chest leads which is a low QRS voltage. Low QRS voltage is arbitrarily defined as peak-to-trough QRS amplitudes of ≤5 mm in the six limb leads and/or ≤10 mm in the chest leads. For left ventricular hypertrophy, Multiple voltage criteria have been proposed based on the presence of tall left precordial R waves and deep right precordial S waves (e.g., SV1 + [RV5 or RV6 ] >35 mm). Repolarization abnormalities (ST depression with T-wave inversions, formerly called the left ventricular “strain” pattern) also may appear in leads with prominent R waves. For Low QRS voltage, multiple factors may be responsible. Among the most serious include pericardial or pleural effusions, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, infiltrative cardiomyopathies, and anasarca.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the casualty with chest pain. The pain intensified by lying supine and was relieved by sitting up and leaning forward. His ECG was done and was below. The diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acute pericarditis In Acute pericarditis, there are diffuse ST-segment elevations in leads I, II, aVF, and V2–V6. There is PR-segment depression due to a concomitant atrial injury current. It typically evolves through four stages. In stage 1, there is a widespread elevation of the ST segments, often with upward concavity, involving two or three standard limb leads and V2 –V6, with reciprocal depressions only in aVR and sometimes V1. Also, there is depression in the PR segment below the TP segment, reflecting atrial involvement. Usually, there are no significant changes in QRS complexes unless a large pericardial effusion develops. After several days, the ST segments return to normal (stage 2), and only then, or even later, do the T waves become inverted (stage 3). Weeks or months after the onset of acute pericarditis, the ECG returns to normal (stage 4).

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- In cardiac tamponade, there are reductions in the amplitude of the QRS complexes, and electrical alternans of the P, QRS, or T waves Option C- In Atrial fibrillation there is the absence of P waves and irregular RR interval. Option D- In contrast, in AMI, ST elevations are upwardly convex, and reciprocal depression is usually more prominent.

questions.text: ECG of an individual shows a PR interval of >0.24 sec and a wide QRS complex. The possible diagnosis is:

options.label: B

options.label: C

questions.correct_answer: B. AV block with delay in distal conducting system
questions.explanation:
Solution:

AV block with delay in distal conducting system The normal PR interval is 12- 0.16 sec PR interval of >0.24 sec is a prolonged PR interval and is seen in the AV block, thus option (d) is incorrect First-degree AV block (PR interval >200 ms) is a slowing of conduction through the AV junction. The site of delay is typically in the AV node but may be in the atria, bundle of His, or His-Purkinje system. A wide QRS is suggestive of a delay in the distal conduction system.

questions.correct_answer: B. Broadening and peaking of T waves – is seen in Hyperkalemia
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Broadening and peaking of T waves – is seen in Hyperkalemia In hyperkalemia- narrowing and peaking (tenting) of the T waves are seen Hyperkalemia produces a sequence of changes, usually beginning with the narrowing and peaking (tenting) of the T waves. Further elevation of extracellular K+ leads to AV conduction disturbances, diminution in P-wave amplitude, and widening of the QRS interval. Severe hyperkalemia eventually causes cardiac arrest with a slow sinusoidal type of mechanism ( “sine-wave” pattern ) followed by asystole.
